description.narrative: This proposed Global Procurement Initiative: Kenya Procurement Orientation Visit will sponsor up to 15 government officials and one U.S. Embassy representative to visit Washington, DC and one other locality. The proposed Orientation Visit would support the Government of Kenya's ongoing efforts to establish a fair, transparent procurement system that utilizes international best practices.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - KTDA Solar Power and Battery Storage, through K & M Advisors LLC

description.narrative: This feasibility study ("Study") grant will support KTDA Power Company Limited to develop small-scale power generation with battery storage options at its tea processing sites across Kenya, which will lead to approximately 30 megawatts of electricity and reduce operating costs for tea production in Kenya. The Study will be conducted by K&M Advisors LLC (Chevy Chase, MD) and includes a demand study, implementation plan, and identification of U.S. sources of supply.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Training - Worldwide: GPI Procurement Assistance Program for Kenya, through Business Council for International Understanding

description.narrative: The Global Procurement Initiative (GPI): Understanding Best Value Prcourement Assistance Program for Kenya is a national-level Program made up of three components: (1) virtual trainings composed of 12 webinars or forums organized into three mini-series, (2) a three day in-country workshop in Nairobi and (3) a 12-13 calendar day study tour to the United States for public procurement leaders. The goal of the Program is to build upon technical skills required to be able to procure infrastructure utilizing value-based evaluation methods and life-cycle cost analysis. A three-year Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) would be signed with Kenyas National Treasury and Planning Ministry to establish the Government of Kenya as the 14th GPI partner country under the Global Procurement Initiative. The Program will be carried out in collaboration with Kenyas National Treasury and Planning Ministry, the George Washington (GW) University Law Schools Government Procurement Law Program and USTDAs GPI technical specialists.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

The goal of the Program is to build upon technical skills required to be able to procure infrastructure utilizing value-based evaluation methods and life-cycle cost analysis.

title.narrative: Technical Symposium - Global Procurement Initiative: Understanding Best Value Technical Assistance for the Government of Kenya, through Enterprise - United States Unknown

description.narrative: This technical assistance (TA) grant provides funding for technical advisory services to assist national and county-level procuring and oversight entities in Kenya as part of USTDA's Global Procurement Initiative: Understanding Best Value (GPI) partnership with the Government of Kenya (GoK). The technical assistance is composed of four separate components: (1) the development of a Value-for-Money (VfM) Procurement Manual; (2) training on how to implement and roll out the guidelines and procedures detailed in the Manual; (3) in-depth training on LCCA; and (4) the development of a Public Procurement Guide for Vendors/Suppliers on VfM guidelines.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - GEOTHERMAL DEVELOPMENT COMPANY CAPACITY BUILDING PROJECT, through Government of Kenya

description.narrative: This $641,000 grant to Kenya's Geothermal Development Company (GDC) assists GDC in improving its capabilities to succeed in the development of Kenya's goethermal energy potential. GDC, a 100% Government of Kenya (GOK) owned corporation, was established in 2008 to accelerate the development of Kenya's geothermal potential, estimated at 7,000 megawatts (MW). GDC has responsibility for undertaking exploration drilling and appraisal drilling at known geothermal fields and the production and development of steam supplies. GDC sells this steam to power producers, including the country's power company KenGen and private investors. As a fledgling organization, GDC is seeking USTDA assistance to develop its capacity to develop feed-in tariffs and evaluate potential partners for power purchase agreements.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Virunga Hydropower Project, through Kleinschmidt Associates

description.narrative: A grant to Virunga Power Kenya Limited funds a feasibility study ("Study") to support the development of three run-of-river hydroelectric plants that would supply 15.7 megawatts of additional generation capacity in rural Kenya. The Study will assess the technical and economic viability of the Project and provide the data and analysis necessary to secure financing for implementation. A U.S. contractor to complete the Study will be competitively selected through the Federal Business Opportunities website.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Olkaria Geothermal Power Total Flow Topping Unit, through Langson Energy, Inc.

description.narrative: Olkaria Geothermal Power Total Flow Unit Feasibility Study

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Olkaria Geothermal Power Total Flow Unit, through Langson Energy, Inc.

description.narrative: A USTDA grant is funding a feasibility study for the Kenya Electric Generating Company Limited ("KenGen") that would support the implementation of a total flow topping unit to generate electricity from waste energy at KenGen's OW-733 geothermal well and assess the viability of deploying total flow topping units at other well sites in the Olkaria geothermal field in Kenya ("Project"). The feasibility study includes technical and financial analysis of the proposed Project and training. A U.S. company, Langson Energy, Inc. (Carson City, NV) is performing the feasibility study. A USTDA grant of $487,500 is funding a feasibility study for the Kenya Electric Generating Company Limited ("KenGen") that would support the implementation of a total flow unit to generate electricity from underutilized energy at KenGen's OW-927A geothermal well and assess the viability of deploying total flow units at other well sites in the Olkaria geothermal field in Kenya ("Project"). The feasibility study includes technical and financial analysis of the Project and training for KenGen staff. A U.S. company, Langson Energy, Inc. (Carson City, NV) is performing the feasibility study.

title.narrative: Lamu Gas-To-Power, through Nexant, Inc.

description.narrative: This feasibility study grant funds an evaluation of the technical, economic, environmental and other critical aspects of a proposed the proposed Lamu gas-to-power project on Pate Island in Lamu County, in Kenya. The feasibility study will focus on the initial phase of the Lamu gas-to-power project, which will increase access to affordable, reliable electricity in Kenya by adding 50-200 MW of new electricity generation capacity.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Nyakwere Hills 40 MW Solar Power Plant, through Castalia LLC

description.narrative: A USTDA grant for technical assistance ("Technical Assistance") will support the development of a 40 megawatt solar photovoltaic power plant in Kenya ("Project") being developed by Quaint Energy Kenya Limited. The Technical Assistance includes reviewing and updating prior feasibility studies and assessments; developing a technical design package and budget required for implementation; and providing technical support for the negotiation and execution of the power purchase and financing agreements for the Project. Castalia LLC is serving as the sole-source U.S. contractor to complete the Technical Assistance. Implementation of the Project would increase installed renewable energy generation capacity, help to electrify new households and businesses in Kenya, and reduce or avoid an estimate 44,100 tons of carbon dioxide equivalent per year as an alternative to fossil fuel power sources. The Technical Assistance would support the U.S. government's Power Africa initiative by helping to catalyze private sector investment in Sub-Saharan Africa's energy sector and increase access to power.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles
